_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for management and prevention of risks associated with the storage and use of chlorine, a regulated toxic substance, at Carolina RWWTP. The RMP was prepared in compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 and Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112(1). The Prevention Elements build upon the facility's Process Safety Management (PSM) System prepared in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is PRASA's policy to comply with applicable Federal and Puerto Rico requirements. The disinfection process at the Carolina RWWTP uses chlorine, a hazardous toxic substance regulated by EPA, OSHA, PROSHO, and EQB. Due to the hazardous characteristics of chlorine, the Carolina RWWTP observes various safety precautions in the storage, conveyance and use of chlorine. The safety precautions are necessary to protect employees, contractors, and visitors at the Carolina RWWTP and the immediate surrounding areas. Safety precautions include procedures and equipment to minimize the potential for accidental release as well as a written emergency program for response to any chlorine release that may occur.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Carolina RWWTP outfall terminates in a high-rate diffuser located in the Atlantic Ocean. Chlorine is used to treat the water in order to eliminate objectionable odors.



Chlorine is delivered to the facility via truck in 1-ton containers.  Chlorine containers are connected to vacuum chlorinators, a system that regulates vacuum and chlorine flow in the system.



Prevention Program



The Prevention Program is composed of many elements and its objective is to prevent accidents and protect the human health, the environment and the property.



Emergency Response Program



PRASA has an emergency response program. Chlorine gas detectors are located within the storage area for early detection a

nd warning of any leak. Leak repair kits are maintained on site, and operators are trained in how to quickly stop any leak that may occur. The emergency response program is coordinated with the local Emergency Response Agency (EQB) for notification of the public. PRASA periodically conducts various training programs, including emergency response training. 



Five-year Accident History



Within the past five years there have been no unplanned releases of chlorine in excess of 10 pounds resulting in injuries or significant property damage on site or known offsite injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Audits



The last compliance audit was conducted on May 13,2016. The expected date of completion all audit findings will be December 31, 2016.
